Carver Sorensen And Alison Chen

Project 2: Netfilter

Project Report

<br>

1. The design of your module

Our init\_module initializes a list as a container (using Linux&#39;s list.h) and creates Netfilter hooks that will filter incoming and outgoing packets based on their IP addresses. Whenever the user writes to the proc file, our write\_proc function will parse the user&#39;s input and act accordingly. The list will grow as the user writes to the proc file asking the kernel module to monitor or block IP addresses. Each &quot;entry&quot; in the list is a struct that contains the IP address and other important information about the IP address (like whether or not the IP address is being monitored and the number of packets it is receiving).

 ![](data:image/*;base64,)

If an IP address is being monitored and not blocked, the numberOfPacketsReceived will increment as packets are directed to that IP address. If an IP address is being monitored and blocked, the numberOfPacketsBlocked will increase instead. If an IP address is being blocked and not monitored, the packets associated with that IP address will be dropped but the numberOfPacketsBlocked will stay at 0 because that value is not being tracked. An IP address will taken off the list when it is no longer being monitored AND no longer being blocked.

If the user wants to drop all incoming/outgoing packets: the module sets the global variable blockAllIn/blockAllOut to true. When the Netfilterhook calls hook\_func (for incoming packets) or hook\_func\_outgoing (for outgoing packets), the first thing hook\_func/hook\_func\_outgoing does is check if blockAllIn/blockAllOut is true. If it is, it will drop the packet immediately.

Finally when the user removes the module with the sudo rmmod command, the cleanup\_module() will unregister the hooks and free the contents of the list in a memory safe manner.

<br><br>

2. How the netfilter works and what kinds of hooks there are

A Netfilter is a series of hooks inside the Linux kernel which allows specific kernel modules to register callback functions with the kernel&#39;s networking stack. Those functions are called for every packet that traverses the hook within the networking stack. There are many kinds of hooks: there are hooks NF\_IP\_LOCAL\_OUT and NF\_IP\_LOCAL\_IN which are used for altering the destination of local packets. For nonlocal packets, NF\_IP\_PRE\_ROUTING and NF\_IP\_POST\_ROUTING hooks for destination and source alterations.

The kernel module registers and unregisters a function by calling nf\_register\_hook/nf\_unregister\_hook. Inside the actual hook function, the module can do things like packet filtering and network address translation, and port translation. Packet filtering is done by telling the net filter to do things like NF\_ACCEPT (accept the packet), NF DROP (drop the packet), or NF\_REPEAT (call the hook again).

<br><br>

3. The design of the user interaction, including the format of the commands a user can specify and what they do.

In order for the user to load the kernel module into the kernel, he or she must use the &quot;sudo insmod ./netfilter.c&quot; command. At this point the proc file will be written and the hook functions registered. The user will then use the command line function cat to give standard input and write to the /proc/filter file that is instantiated in the module&#39;s proc\_create\_entry function. This standard input from the user will use the beginning command cat, a command to filter an IP(s), and an End Of File string. We made the design decision to only allow one command to be written to the file at a time.

Open stdin for file:

- cat &lt;&lt;EOF&gt;&gt; /proc/filter
  - Starts the input stream

One of the following commands to write:

- IP [address] [b/ub/m/um]
  - &quot;b&quot; will block specified IP
  - &quot;ub&quot; will unblock specified IP
  - &quot;m&quot; will monitor specified IP
  - &quot;um&quot; will unmonitor specified IP
- ALLO [b/u]
  - &quot;b&quot; will block all IPs Outgoing
  - &quot;u&quot; will unblock all IPs Outgoing
- ALLI [b/u]
  - &quot;b&quot; will block all IPs Incoming
  - &quot;u&quot; will unblock all IPs Incoming
- STATS [ALL/ [IP address]]
  - &quot;ALL&quot; will print out each IP&#39;s statistics while monitored
  - &quot;[IP address]&quot; will print out the specified IP&#39;s statistics while monitored

End Of File:

- EOF
  - Ends the input stream

Notes: When working with the ALLI and ALLO commands to block all IPs that are incoming and outgoing respectively, we made the decision that these commands should always block the incoming/outgoing IPs until the unblock command for ALLI/ALLO is given. This means it only functions as a primary test. For example if the following was written to /proc:

- IP 1.1.0.127 b
- ALLI b
- ALLO b
- IP 1.1.0.127 ub

The IP 1.1.0.127 would still be blocked until the ALLI/ALLO was unblocked. We confirmed with Professor Balasubramanian that this was an acceptable design decision.

Further more, we designed the module in such a way that the packet counts for blocked and received would only be incremented if the user explicitly monitors that IP.

To remove the module, the user uses &quot;sudo insmod netfilter.ko&quot;.

<br><br>

4. Describe how you tested your project.

We tested the project through a series of manual tests, which included expected and unexpected user behavior. Below is an example write to the proc file, &quot;filter&quot;, created when the module is loaded into the kernel.

Example write to proc:

cat &lt;&lt;EOF&gt;&gt; /proc/filter

&gt; IP 1.1.0.127

&gt; EOF

For testing:

1. First we tested our ALLO commands
    1. &quot;Sudo insmod ./netfilter.ko&quot; in the directory that file is located
    2. Write &quot;ALLO b&quot; to proc file
    3. Bring up a browser and try to go to google.com
    4. &quot;tail -f /var/log/kern.log&quot; to bring up kernel log
    5. All packets passing through the kernel should be logged with all outgoing packets being dropped
    6. The browser should not be able to find google.com
    7. Write &quot;ALLO u&quot; to proc file
    8. Run steps 3 and 4
    9. All packets should be accepted and the browser should reach google.com and return
    10. &quot;Sudo rmmod ./netfilter.ko&quot; in the directory that file is located
2. Then we tested our ALLI commands
    1. &quot;Sudo insmod ./netfilter.ko&quot; in the directory that file is located
    2. Write &quot;ALLI b&quot; to proc file
    3. Bring up a browser and try to go to google.com
    4. &quot;tail -f /var/log/kern.log&quot; to bring up kernel log
    5. All packets passing through the kernel should be logged with all incoming packets being dropped
    6. The browser should continuously wait for google.com to return (it wont)
    7. Write &quot;ALLI u&quot; to proc file
    8. Run steps 3 and 4
    9. All packets should be accepted and the browser should reach google.com and return.
    10. &quot;Sudo rmmod ./netfilter.ko&quot; in the directory that file is located
3. Then we tested IP addresses and STATS
    1. By putting printk statements with ACCEPT or DROP in their appropriate areas along with the address string of the source/destination (depending on incoming/outgoing)
    2. &quot;Sudo insmod ./netfilter.ko&quot; in the directory that file is located
    3. Opened Browser and went to google.com (leave this up in background, may periodically have to refresh to get a new influx of packets)
    4. Find 2 IPs (in our case: 36.11.217.172 and 29.91.21.72)
    5. Write &quot;IP 36.11.217.172 b&quot; to proc file
    6. Check kern.log to check if 36.11.217.172&#39;s packets now drop and that a new IP was added to the list
    7. Write &quot;IP 29.91.21.72 b&quot; to proc file
    8. Check kern.log to check if 29.91.21.72&#39;s packets now drop and that a new IP was added to the list
    9. Write &quot;IP 36.11.217.172 m&quot; to proc file
    10. Wait for packets
    11. Write &quot;STATS ALL&quot; to proc file
    12. Check that only 36.11.217.172 has a printed entry in stats with some number in the PacketsBlocked count and a 0 for the PacketsReceived count.
    13. Write &quot;IP 29.91.21.72 m&quot; to proc file
    14. Write &quot;IP 36.11.217.172 ub&quot; to proc file
    15. Check kern.log to check if 36.11.217.172&#39;s packets no longer drop
    16. Wait for packets
    17. Write &quot;STATS ALL&quot; to proc file
    18. Check that both IPs have printed entries in stats. Check that 36.11.217.172&#39;s entry has some number in the PacketsBlocked count and the PacketsReceived count. Check that 29.91.21.72&#39;s entry has some number in the PacketsBlocked count and a 0 the PacketsReceived count.
    19. Repeat steps 14-18 for 29.91.21.72 and check that the PacketsReceived count is no longer 0.
    20. Write &quot;STATS 29.91.21.72 &quot; to proc file
    21. Write &quot;STATS 36.11.217.172&quot; to proc file
    22. Check that the same entries for both of these IPs returned (must check if either address had a packet filtered and increased a count)
    23. Write &quot;IP 29.91.21.72 um&quot; to proc file
    24. Check kern.log to see if node freed.
    25. Write &quot;STATS ALL&quot; to proc file
    26. Check that the 29.91.21.72 entry is gone, but the 36.11.217.172 entry is still there.
    27. Write &quot;STATS 1.1.1.1&quot; to proc file
    28. Check that the kern.log printed that IP address was not being monitored
    29. Repeat steps 23-26 for 36.11.217.172, and check that STATS does not have any entries.
    30. Check kern.log to make sure packets with either of the addresses 36.11.217.172 or 29.91.21.72 do not drop.
    31. &quot;Sudo rmmod ./netfilter.ko&quot; in the directory that file is located
4. Test for supported proc file writes
    1. Write &quot;IPP 29.91.21.72 b&quot; to proc file
    2. Write &quot;IP 29.91.21.72 n&quot; to proc file
    3. Write &quot;ALLO d&quot; to proc file
    4. All of these entries should tell the user they are &quot;cat: write error: Operation not permitted &quot;
5. Test for node clean up
    1. &quot;Sudo insmod ./netfilter.ko&quot; in the directory that file is located
    2. Write &quot;IP 29.91.21.72 b&quot; to proc file
    3. &quot;Sudo rmmod ./netfilter.ko&quot; in the directory that file is located
    4. Check kern.log to see if node freed

<br><br>

5. How you would implement more advanced functionality such as a stateful firewall. A stateful firewall is just a firewall that tracks the op

I would create a firewall that keeps track of the state of network connections (such as TCP streams or UDP communication). In the hook function that is registered for filtering packets, you can just check if the packet&#39;s protocol number corresponds with UDP (17) or TCP (6). When dealing with TCP protocol, all packets with &quot;SYN&quot; in their header received by the firewall signify opening a new connection. If the connection has been authenticated bidirectionally through a successful three way handshake associated with TCP (&quot;SYN, SYN-ACK, ACK&quot;) the firewall will receive the &quot;ACK&quot; response and transfer the connection to an established state. With both TCP and UDP connection protocol, an established connection between source and destination will be remembered as an entry in the firewall&#39;s state table. In this way, my stateful firewall can use a state table to remember which connections are established and see which connections are new in order to make decisions based on past information.

Since UDP connections are stateless, you can just check the fire wall rules to decide if you want to let the packet through the firewall. An example of a rule on the fire wall rule list might be &quot;we will allow the packet in if the packet is an incoming packet on port 80 (a popular port associated with web services) and is part of an established connection&quot;. **If the inspected packet matches that existing firewall rule, the packet is passed in and an entry is added to the state table. From that point on, because the packets in that particular communication session match an existing state table entry, they are allowed access without having to look through the firewall rule list.** If the packet doesn&#39;t match any rule on the list, it will be dropped.

Implementation-wise, I would have a function/method that contained all my rules. I would use a list (using Linux&#39;s list.h) for the firewall&#39;s state table. To differentiate between UDP and TCP I would do something like this in the hook function:

    struct iphdr \*ip\_header = (struct iphdr \*)skb\_network\_header(skb);
    if (ip\_header-&gt;protocol==17) {
        //UDP
    } else if (ip\_header-&gt;protocol == 6) {
        //TCP
    }

<br><br>

6. Describe, with netfilter specific terms, how you would enforce a quota on how much traffic a user can generate to/from a specific address

We would enforce a quota on how much traffic a user can generate from a specific address by just monitoring a specific address. When monitoring an address, the kernel module we wrote keeps count of how many packets that IP address is receiving. You can check in the hook function where you are incrementing the number of packets whether or not that number goes past a certain number (whatever the quota is). After a certain amount of packets that you NF\_ACCEPT, you can decide there is too much traffic coming from that IP address. Once the number of packets received goes past that number, just NF\_DROP all the packets from that IP address.

After a set amount of time, reset the count to 0 and unblock the IP address if it was blocked.

<br><br>

7. Explain why the Linux kernel does not have a binary kernel interface (this is one of the reasons that the sample netfilter code in some of the links above doesn&#39;t work on newer versions of the Linux kernel). This article will help: http://www.kroah.com/log/linux/stable\_api\_nonsense.html

The Linux kernel must be able to support additional architectures or changing kernel structures at a very rapid pace. A binary kernel structure means that the kernel module must be built one-to-one with every variable of an OS and all of the changing dependencies/structures/functions. This means that if a single parameter were to change, but I am still using the same architecture, the update would be made. But it would also have to be made to every other version.

To avoid incredible amounts of work and ensure source code being somewhat portable, the Linux kernel is a stable interface. To deal with the inevitable changes to kernel structure, functions, etc., one can have a single version of the module built into the GPL where all developers can see the module. Then when updates are made, the module can be updated to the most recent kernel changes, but that does not change per architecture. So that way when a new Linux kernel comes out and there isn&#39;t an exact architecture implementation for that new version, it will not work correctly. We see this through some of the sample module source code given to us. The kernel headers must be changed to meet the new version, since the implementations are not kept up to date for every architecture variant.
